result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Marissa Q. Schelke

records.addlTxt: Plea/sentencing hearing on November 21, 2022 at 02:40 pm.

Defendant appears in person. 

M.S. sworn and testifies. 
Court questions defendant RE: Employment/Income. 
Court appoints Attorney Peter Rotter @ $100/hr. not to exceed $1,000 without further order of the Court. 

Adj: 9:44 am.
Indigency hearing on August 8, 2022 at 09:30 am.

Indigency hearing on August 4, 2022 at 09:30 am.
Pre-trial conference on October 12, 2022 at 01:40 pm.
Preliminary Hearing on November 21, 2022 at 02:40 pm.

No contact with victim(s): Monique Ysquierdo. Contact includes direct personal or physical and indirect contact by phone, in writing of any kind, entry to the person's residence or place of employment together with contacts through other persons.  Contact, however, may be made through the defendant's attorney. Absolute sobriety from and no possession of controlled substances except prescriptions taken as presribed.
